ygData.subject: Musings On Lessons Learned From BlindBuilder Applied To NEAT & Indirect Encoding
ygData.msgSnippet: Alex, Your prior work associated w/ BlindBuilder I believe is informative and applicable to possible updates to NEAT and indirect encodings in general. The

Subject: Musings On Lessons Learned From BlindBuilder Applied To NEAT & Indirect Encoding
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=487025037; y=7_gLissfyfhybrHJxEVCGBIHU3qaxXiHqptsOxnXKb-rAg
X-Yahoo-Profile: afcarl2

Alex,
     Your prior work associated w/ BlindBuilder I believe is informat=
ive and applicable to possible updates to NEAT and indirect encodings in ge=
neral. The growing disruptive impact of construction operators as the size =
of the construction plan increases, seemly undercuts the benefit of compact=
 nature of the approach, and also illustrates a fundamental strength and we=
akness of NEAT. NEAT, starting from minimal size, mitigates the disruptive =
nature of various operators at the beginning allowing for more effective us=
e of computational resources for growing of the organism in a profitable po=
rtion of the design space. But as organism size increases, the growing disr=
uptive impact of some operators, and where they are applied, increasingly b=
og down further progress.
     In the context of BlindBuilder, two examples=
 are useful:
1) Bridge: The concept of a bridge is simple and straight forw=
ard. From a construction perspective, could be achieved with a single eleme=
nt of appropriate size and orientation. While the size of the construction =
plan is vastly different based upon the characteristics of the formative el=
ements, though the concept is still simple, the disruptive impact of variou=
s operators on form, fit, function and convergence is also vastly different=
.
2) Wall: Also, the concept of a wall is simple and straight forward. And =
again from a construction perspective, could be achieved with a single elem=
ent of appropriate size and orientation. The same comments also apply regar=
ding construction plan size and associated disruptive impact of constructio=
n operators.
     The point being, that the sensitivity of the concept shou=
ld not be subject to the scale of the formative elements, but rather the su=
itability of the formulation to the objectives of the concept. In the const=
ruction context, this is more straight forward. The overall objective is co=
mposed of a relatively few well known concepts taken together in some relat=
ive orientations WRT each other (i.e. a house can be composed of four ortho=
gonal walls and a roof). The construction operators should be confined to r=
efinement of suitability of the formative elements and their orientations t=
aken together WRT the individual concept, guided by concept specific operat=
or selection criteria (i.e. semi-separable multi-subobjectives).
    Of cou=
rse, in the general case, the identification of concepts is not as straight=
 forward. But efforts to identify reusable genetic material snippets would =
most likely qualify as identification of concepts, and would thus likely be=
nefit from: a) partitioning of the genome for application of operators, and=
 b) application of concept specific operator selection WRT concept suitabil=
ity for the current overall objective.

Andy
